revisions:
[{'created': '2019-03-06 23:52:24.000000000', 'message': 'Add functional recreate test for bug 1818914

The confirm resize flow in the compute manager
runs on the source host. It calls RT.drop_move_claim
to drop resource usage from the source host for the
old flavor. The problem with drop_move_claim is it
only decrements the old flavor from the reported usage
if the instance is in RT.tracked_migrations, which will
only be there on the source host if the update_available_resource
periodic task runs before the resize is confirmed, otherwise
the instance is still just tracked in RT.tracked_instances on
the source host. This leaves the source compute incorrectly
reporting resource usage for the old flavor until the next
periodic runs, which could be a large window if resizes are
configured to automatically confirm, e.g. resize_confirm_window=1,
and the periodic interval is big, e.g. update_resources_interval=600.

This change adds a functional recreate test for the bug which will
be updated in the change that fixes the bug.

Change-Id: I4aac187283c2f341b5c2712be85f722156e14f63
Related-Bug: #1818914
Related-Bug: #1498126

commit_message:
Add functional recreate test for bug 1818914

The confirm resize flow in the compute manager
runs on the source host. It calls RT.drop_move_claim
to drop resource usage from the source host for the
old flavor. The problem with drop_move_claim is it
only decrements the old flavor from the reported usage
if the instance is in RT.tracked_migrations, which will
only be there on the source host if the update_available_resource
periodic task runs before the resize is confirmed, otherwise
the instance is still just tracked in RT.tracked_instances on
the source host. This leaves the source compute incorrectly
reporting resource usage for the old flavor until the next
periodic runs, which could be a large window if resizes are
configured to automatically confirm, e.g. resize_confirm_window=1,
and the periodic interval is big, e.g. update_resources_interval=600.

This change adds a functional recreate test for the bug which will
be updated in the change that fixes the bug.

Change-Id: I4aac187283c2f341b5c2712be85f722156e14f63
Related-Bug: #1818914
Related-Bug: #1498126

[{'created': '2019-04-18 19:25:21.000000000', 'message': 'WIP lvm: Only use initiators when comparing connector dicts

Previously when checking if it was safe to terminate a volumes
connection the provided connector dict was compared against the
connectors of any active attachment associated to the volume.

This would however fail if any of the attachments were created with
connectors that used a different mountpoint within the instance to that
of the provided connector and would result in the terminate connection
being called prematurely.

This change corrects this by only comparing the initiator key of the
connectors ensuring terminate connection is only called when a single
attachment remains on a given host using a specific initiator.

Change-Id: Icabc4a67d3f5462fe24e4027e84e56a001e1b2b8
'}, {'created': '2019-04-23 10:39:13.000000000', 'message': 'lvm: Only use initiators when comparing connector dicts

commit_message:
lvm: Only use initiators when comparing connector dicts

Ib5aa1b7578f7d3200185566ff5f8634dd519d020 previously fixed the premature
termination of multi attached iSCSI/LVM volumes by comparing the
provided connector dict against that stored with any remaining active
attachments. Only allowing the termination to proceed if a single active
attachment remained using the provided connector.

However this check fails if two instances on the same host are connected
to the same multi attach volume using different mountpoints as these are
now stored within the connector. This behaviour was introduced during
Queens by If3afe8d8bd6b8c327ccc7d1140053bccaf7e1ad7 and
I11ba269c3f7a2e7707b2b7e27d26eb7a2c948a82 to workaround differences
between the cinderv2 and cinderv3 APIs.

This change corrects this by only comparing the initiator key of the
connectors ensuring terminate connection is only called when a single
attachment remains on a given host using a specific initiator.

Closes-Bug: #1825957
Change-Id: Icabc4a67d3f5462fe24e4027e84e56a001e1b2b8

commit_message:
nova: reduce playbooks runs to control/compute

During deployment or upgrades, there isn't a reason to deploy a
service after another.  There is no documented requirement for the
order of upgrades either.

We also start services in a specific order using the systemd_service
role which means that we can simplify this into two main role includes,
control plane and data plane (computes).  This is to make sure that
our upgrades are completed cleanly.

Depends-On: I506ba4fc6b134ef0b389a2647fe22ae6b1a17ace
Change-Id: I98ca698478e24b65b52b2b3b10052532b8425976

commit_message:
Update all Stein and master jobs to use Ceph Nautilus

From the OpenStack Stein release we want to deploy the Ceph Nautilus
version; this change is meant to update all configs accordingly.

Change-Id: Id0de75e7459b9a8d993a87552b51cf6fdbd29687
Depends-On: I1782d2fcf558c0d41f49da53cfeccd015df38cde

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-02-28 22:38:50.000000000', 'message': 'Move legacy-grenade-dsvm-neutron-multinode-live-migration in-tree

This moves the legacy-grenade-dsvm-neutron-multinode-live-migration
job from openstack-zuul-jobs in-tree. Nova is the only project
that runs this job and this allows nova to directly manage it.

The job will still use the same irrelevant-files list and is still
non-voting for the time being and only runs in the check queue.

It has been renamed to "nova-grenade-live-migration".

This change is meant to be backported to rocky, queens and pike
to allow us to drop legacy-grenade-dsvm-neutron-multinode-live-migration
from openstack-zuul-jobs where the job is branchless but restricted
to pike+ branches.

A follow up master-only (stein) change will make the job voting
and gate per the plan in the mailing list [1].

[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-February/003341.html

Conflicts:
      .zuul.yaml

Change-Id: Ie9b61775dbb92b10237688eaddaca606c1c73a23
(cherry picked from commit 53208b0496d78b2f5cd04b1ce0ef5ffcb757e1eb)
(cherry picked from commit 7b9a133bb6374acb0bda32010197641e2f813de6)
(cherry picked from commit 08288b58f5281017ab6eeb981caa295302760f23)

commit_message:
Move legacy-grenade-dsvm-neutron-multinode-live-migration in-tree

This moves the legacy-grenade-dsvm-neutron-multinode-live-migration
job from openstack-zuul-jobs in-tree. Nova is the only project
that runs this job and this allows nova to directly manage it.

The job will still use the same irrelevant-files list and is still
non-voting for the time being and only runs in the check queue.

It has been renamed to "nova-grenade-live-migration".

This change is meant to be backported to rocky, queens and pike
to allow us to drop legacy-grenade-dsvm-neutron-multinode-live-migration
from openstack-zuul-jobs where the job is branchless but restricted
to pike+ branches.

A follow up master-only (stein) change will make the job voting
and gate per the plan in the mailing list [1].

[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-February/003341.html

Conflicts:
      .zuul.yaml

NOTE(mriedem): The conflict is due to commit
70eb288ee7993e384a5bdd383c5bc6c2c0128e5c on Pike.
Also note that due to the opendev rename, grenade has to be
called out as a specific required project and the devstack-gate
and grenade repos had to be fixed in run.yaml.

Change-Id: Ie9b61775dbb92b10237688eaddaca606c1c73a23
(cherry picked from commit 53208b0496d78b2f5cd04b1ce0ef5ffcb757e1eb)
(cherry picked from commit 7b9a133bb6374acb0bda32010197641e2f813de6)
(cherry picked from commit 76418a32cbbcc3ecc3a89bc3ebb0ecc767046da0)

commit_message:
Give some HA router case specific resources

1. give each HA failover case an independent vrrp_id
2. give each HA port an independent IP address, so the
interface IPs for router HA ports will be:
    169.254.192.100 and 169.254.192.101
    169.254.192.102 and 169.254.192.103
    169.254.192.104 and 169.254.192.105
    169.254.192.106 and 169.254.192.107
VIP of each case will be:
    169.254.0.10/24
    169.254.0.11/24
    169.254.0.12/24
    169.254.0.13/24
    169.254.0.14/24

Conflicts:
    neutron/tests/common/l3_test_common.py

Closes-Bug: #1819160
Change-Id: I1216d96af40449ec16a852cc1f6c4f15c85f4546
(cherry picked from commit c69a87405af6b632a3edd9c6fe5ee63a5bc07eb1)
(cherry picked from commit 2c5957f56d46d99b8eb1e7651afcbf8fa9f426a0)

Use Ceph Nautilus for newer OpenStack releases

We want to use Ceph Luminous with the OpenStack Queens and Rocky
releases, then for newer releases we want to use Ceph Nautilus
instead.

subject: Remove stable:follows-policy tag for Trove
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 308, 'name': 'Thierry Carrez', 'email': 'thierry@openstack.org', 'username': 'ttx'}, {'_account_id': 1004, 'name': 'Mohammed Naser', 'email': 'mnaser@vexxhost.com', 'username': 'mnaser'}, {'_account_id': 2472, 'name': 'Doug Hellmann', 'email': 'dhellmann@redhat.com', 'username': 'doug-hellmann'}, {'_account_id': 4257, 'name': 'Zane Bitter', 'email': 'zbitter@redhat.com', 'username': 'zaneb'}, {'_account_id': 5046, 'name': 'Lance Bragstad', 'email': 'lbragstad@redhat.com', 'username': 'ldbragst'}, {'_account_id': 5196, 'name': 'Matthew Treinish', 'email': 'mtreinish@kortar.org', 'username': 'treinish'}, {'_account_id': 6732, 'name': 'Lingxian Kong', 'email': 'anlin.kong@gmail.com', 'username': 'kong'}, {'_account_id': 6873, 'name': 'Matt Riedemann', 'email': 'mriedem.os@gmail.com', 'username': 'mriedem'}, {'_account_id': 8099, 'name': 'Graham Hayes', 'email': 'gr@ham.ie', 'username': 'graham'}, {'_account_id': 8556, 'name': 'Ghanshyam', 'display_name': 'Ghanshyam Mann', 'email': 'gmann@ghanshyammann.com', 'username': 'ghanshyam'}, {'_account_id': 10607, 'name': 'Alexandra Settle', 'email': 'a.settle@outlook.com', 'username': 'asettle'}, {'_account_id': 11655, 'name': 'Julia Kreger', 'email': 'juliaashleykreger@gmail.com', 'username': 'jkreger', 'status': 'On the moon! With a jetpack!'}, {'_account_id': 11904, 'name': 'Sean McGinnis', 'email': 'sean.mcginnis@gmail.com', 'username': 'SeanM'}, {'_account_id': 12898, 'name': 'Tony Breeds', 'email': 'tony@bakeyournoodle.com', 'username': 'tonyb'}, {'_account_id': 13562, 'name': 'Samuel Matzek', 'email': 'smatzek@us.ibm.com', 'username': 'smatzek'}, {'_account_id': 17068, 'name': 'Jean-Philippe Evrard', 'email': 'openstack@a.spamming.party', 'username': 'evrardjp'}, {'_account_id': 22348, 'name': 'Zuul', 'username': 'zuul', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 28695, 'name': 'Bartosz Zurkowski', 'email': 'b.zurkowski@samsung.com', 'username': 'b.zurkowski'}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 6732, 'date': '2019-04-12 14:28:07.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2019-04-12 14:34:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1

This is unfortunate, but given the current state of the trove project I think it probably makes sense to do for the time being. Hopefully by dropping this assertion it will relax some restrictions that will allow the trove team to do what they need to in order to get the project healthy again and at a point where they can regain the assertion.'}, {'account_id': 8099, 'date': '2019-04-12 14:48:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Rollcall-Vote+1

I agree with Sean, this is unfortunate.

As an aside, doing a more in depth review of the projects with this tag may in order. Some of them may have completely different leadership than what was there when they applied it, and may not be as aware of the rules.'}, {'account_id': 8556, 'date': '2019-04-12 15:00:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

I am concerned that, adding the tag is always good but removing is definitely not. and before removing we should know the problem more deeply. 

Some discussion on ML- http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-April/004991.html

It will be good to know the reason and future plan.

I want to understand, is https://review.openstack.org/#/c/651672/ the only case based on which you are taking the decision to remove the  "stable:follows-policy" tag ? Or you think trove will have/need more cases like that?'}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2019-04-12 19:36:49.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I don't think this has ever happened before, and  we are probably lacking some clarity on what it means.

IMHO the stable:follows-policy tag applies to a given project *for a given release*. So removing it now would mean that the Trove team is free to backport features to stable/train in the future. It should *not* mean that they now get to backport features to e.g. stable/rocky - that would be inappropriate IMO, since distros are entitled to rely on stable/rocky continuing to be stable.

However, I'm not sure that we've documented this, I assume that our tooling doen't really capture it, and I'm almost certain that this is not what the Trove team assumes this change means.

TBH I'm also struggling to see how backporting features to old stable branches is essential, or even not unhelpful, to reviving a project, but I guess that's up to the team to decide."}, {'account_id': 6732, 'date': '2019-04-13 05:44:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Commit message was updated.'}, {'account_id': 1004, 'date': '2019-04-14 15:58:06.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

I think the approach here is to make Stein usable in order to make it something that deployers can start using.  The release cycle of 6 months before Trove is 'usable' seems a bit long.

I may be lacking clarity at the state of Trove though, but I believe it's pretty much almost abandoned, and Lingxian has probably done the most _visible_ amount of work on it in the past time."}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2019-04-15 09:46:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Rollcall-Vote+1

On one hand I don't like the idea of stopping following stable policy. I see it as a long-term commitment toward users -- they select a specific component in part because they follow a clear non-breaking policy for stable updates, and removing that assumption from them should be done with extreme caution, and very rarely. I don't think it should be a per-release thing you can opt in or opt out freely. And I think it should affect all stable branches for a given deliverable. 

On the other hand, Trove is currently not "stable" in any way, so following a "stable policy" does not make that much sense. More importantly, I don't want to impede on the necessary work to fix it.

So it might be one of those rare cases, and I think I'm OK with it as long as (1) it's clear it is an exceptional situation, and (2) we communicate clearly about it.'}, {'account_id': 5046, 'date': '2019-04-15 19:45:19.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Rollcall-Vote+1

I agree with others that this is unfortunate, but I think it's important that the tags are accurate."}, {'account_id': 1004, 'date': '2019-04-15 19:49:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Speaking out loud, do we need to perhaps add something to talk about when the stable:follows-policy can be removed?'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2019-04-15 20:37:00.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Rollcall-Vote+1

> Speaking out loud, do we need to perhaps add something to talk
 > about when the stable:follows-policy can be removed?

Right now we have that documented as being up to the stable team's discretion. See https://governance.openstack.org/tc/reference/tags/stable_follows-policy.html#deprecation"}, {'account_id': 10607, 'date': '2019-04-16 12:16:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Rollcall-Vote+1'}, {'account_id': 1004, 'date': '2019-04-17 14:43:50.000000000', 'content': 'Topic changed from remove-trove-stable-policy to formal-vote'}, {'account_id': 11655, 'date': '2019-04-22 19:07:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Rollcall-Vote+1'}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2019-04-23 11:24:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Rollcall-Vote+1'}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2019-04-23 11:25:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: -Rollcall-Vote Code-Review+1

A shy +1 from me. I believe someone from stable policy should review this too first.'}, {'account_id': 8099, 'date': '2019-04-23 20:00:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Rollcall-Vote+1'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2019-04-25 20:32:20.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Code-Review+1

Sure, as mentioned by others I don't think trove is particularly stable anyway, and as mentioned in the commit message it's not widely adopted (as far as I know anyway). I don't think gmann's question was ever answered about there being a specific change that needed to be backported, but I'm also not really sure how much it matters at this point. If there were more stakeholders involved I'd have hoped they'd stand up by now (wasn't IBM doing something with trove for awhile - are they gone now? Thinking Sam Matzek here)."}, {'account_id': 12898, 'date': '2019-04-25 22:07:10.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Code-Review+1

Looks good to me.

I'll follow-up on individual comments next, I agree the stable tag doesn't apply to trove right now.  Once there is a healthy team/community we can look at adding it back."}, {'account_id': 12898, 'date': '2019-04-25 22:14:27.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

> I don't think this has ever happened before, and  we are probably
 > lacking some clarity on what it means.
 > 
 > IMHO the stable:follows-policy tag applies to a given project *for
 > a given release*. So removing it now would mean that the Trove team
 > is free to backport features to stable/train in the future. It
 > should *not* mean that they now get to backport features to e.g.
 > stable/rocky - that would be inappropriate IMO, since distros are
 > entitled to rely on stable/rocky continuing to be stable.

The stable tag applies to all open and maintained stable branches.  Removing this states
that consumers going back to pike can no longer make assertions about what will happen on stable branches.  When a team applies for the tag I litterally review *every* chnage merged on all stable branches.  Sometimes it's clear from the commit message that a change is in or out of policy if not I look at the patch.
 
 > However, I'm not sure that we've documented this, I assume that our
 > tooling doen't really capture it, and I'm almost certain that this
 > is not what the Trove team assumes this change means.

It means they're free to manage the own stable team and, should they chose, they can backport anything they feel is appropriate.  However, just because they cane doesn't mean they will.  Given the minimal community on master I don't know how much time there will be for stable backports.  As a point of order backporting something to stable stein that is against the policy for stable branches will send up a red flag as long as stable it open and in extended maintenance.  This could mean the trove will find it harder to re-obtain the tag until train goes unmaintained in 2+years.  I don't say this as a threat, just being explict about what it means.

I'll get some more docs *somewhere* during the train cycle.  They'll be rough but it'll be better than what we have now.

 > TBH I'm also struggling to see how backporting features to old
 > stable branches is essential, or even not unhelpful, to reviving a
 > project, but I guess that's up to the team to decide."}, {'account_id': 8556, 'date': '2019-04-26 01:41:27.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

> > I don't think this has ever happened before, and  we are probably
 > > lacking some clarity on what it means.
 > >
 > > IMHO the stable:follows-policy tag applies to a given project
 > *for
 > > a given release*. So removing it now would mean that the Trove
 > team
 > > is free to backport features to stable/train in the future. It
 > > should *not* mean that they now get to backport features to e.g.
 > > stable/rocky - that would be inappropriate IMO, since distros are
 > > entitled to rely on stable/rocky continuing to be stable.
 > 
 > The stable tag applies to all open and maintained stable branches. 
 > Removing this states
 > that consumers going back to pike can no longer make assertions
 > about what will happen on stable branches.  When a team applies for
 > the tag I litterally review *every* chnage merged on all stable
 > branches.  Sometimes it's clear from the commit message that a
 > change is in or out of policy if not I look at the patch.
 > 
 > > However, I'm not sure that we've documented this, I assume that
 > our
 > > tooling doen't really capture it, and I'm almost certain that
 > this
 > > is not what the Trove team assumes this change means.
 > 
 > It means they're free to manage the own stable team and, should
 > they chose, they can backport anything they feel is appropriate. 
 > However, just because they cane doesn't mean they will.  Given the
 > minimal community on master I don't know how much time there will
 > be for stable backports.  As a point of order backporting something
 > to stable stein that is against the policy for stable branches will
 > send up a red flag as long as stable it open and in extended
 > maintenance.  This could mean the trove will find it harder to
 > re-obtain the tag until train goes unmaintained in 2+years.  I
 > don't say this as a threat, just being explict about what it means.

This is an important point about when Trove can re-obtain the tag and Trove team/PTL should be aware of this before we remove the tag.  

@tony do we have that policy written somewhere ? this is happening first time so we should clearly write about the re-obtain constraint. Otherwise it might be the case when team remove the tag in one cycle and try to obtain in next cycle. 

I am ok to remove the tag but before that we should write about what tony mentioned here which is important for team to ask for removal of tag. 

 > 
 > I'll get some more docs *somewhere* during the train cycle. 
 > They'll be rough but it'll be better than what we have now.
 > 
 > > TBH I'm also struggling to see how backporting features to old
 > > stable branches is essential, or even not unhelpful, to reviving
 > a
 > > project, but I guess that's up to the team to decide."}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2019-04-26 07:43:49.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: -Code-Review

Lingxian Kong, could you confirm this is what you do, and you don't intent to apply stable policy for the next 2+ years?

Thanks."}, {'account_id': 6732, 'date': '2019-04-26 11:14:50.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Hi @all, I can't guarantee what will happen in the next 2 years, but I won't apply for the same tag as long as I'm in the Trove team. Thanks for all your suggestion, I know what I'm doing."}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2019-04-26 11:42:16.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Rollcall-Vote+1

> Hi @all, I can't guarantee what will happen in the next 2 years,
 > but I won't apply for the same tag as long as I'm in the Trove
 > team. Thanks for all your suggestion, I know what I'm doing.

Then voting positively"}, {'account_id': 5196, 'date': '2019-04-26 16:26:44.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Code-Review+1

I'm fine with this too given the current state of the trove project. But, it also raises larger questions for me though because as an end user of trove (hypothetically as I don't actually use it) does the tag removal provide enough of a signal that I don't have the stable policy guarantees I've come to expect? 

Although thinking back to a few years ago even when there was more active contribution to trove I seem to remember tension with the trove team and the stable policy back then too, so maybe no users actually expect trove to follow the stable policy (regardless of the tag) and this isn't a concern."}, {'account_id': 8556, 'date': '2019-04-26 18:00:13.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: -Code-Review

> Hi @all, I can't guarantee what will happen in the next 2 years,

Thanks lxkong for ack and confirmation. I am ok with the tag removal 
 now and thanks for your hard work on Trove stability."}, {'account_id': 8556, 'date': '2019-04-26 18:00:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Rollcall-Vote+1

Adding the more clarity on tag removal and re-obtaining process for future ref - https://review.opendev.org/#/c/655984'}, {'account_id': 1004, 'date': '2019-04-27 08:51:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Rollcall-Vote+1 Workflow+1'}]

[{'created': '2019-04-12 14:28:07.000000000', 'message': 'Remove stable:follows-policy tag for Trove

Change-Id: I14e1377e87b3fa16c1414ae9a780144d48ca213e
'}, {'created': '2019-04-13 05:44:12.000000000', 'message': "Remove stable:follows-policy tag for Trove

The reason for this proposal is that Trove team would like to manage the
way how stable branch is maintained, the original discussion is here[1].
There are several things argued in the discussion, self-approve policy
and stable branch permission. Removing the stable:follows-policy tag is
just aiming at solving the latter.

I don't know the history that when Trove added the tag, but I personally
don't think that applies to Trove for now. The tag is useful especially
for the projects that are adopted universally in production, which means
there are lots of people care about the stability and maintainability of
the projects. It's good for those projects to follow some policies to
achieve that.

However, Trove is no longer a project that was backed by Tesora, the
previous PTL came from Tesora left, all of the core reviewers left.
Until now, I've never heard there is company using Trove in production
except a private cloud in Samsung, maybe there are some others, but
seems they don't care about the open source community[2]. As mentioned
in my PTL candidacy, the highest priority for Trove is to give the
potential users confidence that the project is still actively
maintained, the team(well, mostly myself) is trying very hard to improve
DevStack and improve the way to build Trove guest image, in the near
future, I will solve the security issue as well, because those issues
were always asked when the developers or operators started the project
evaluation. With all that said, we need to decide what is going to be
backported by ourselves, sometimes even features or patches that don't
satisfy the stable branch policy. I don't see there are many advantages
to involve Stable Branch Maintenance team.

Hopefully, the project could get the tag back in the future.

[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-April/004991.html
[2] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-January/001934.html

Change-Id: I14e1377e87b3fa16c1414ae9a780144d48ca213e
"}]
commit_message:
Remove stable:follows-policy tag for Trove

The reason for this proposal is that Trove team would like to manage the
way how stable branch is maintained, the original discussion is here[1].
There are several things argued in the discussion, self-approve policy
and stable branch permission. Removing the stable:follows-policy tag is
just aiming at solving the latter.

I don't know the history that when Trove added the tag, but I personally
don't think that applies to Trove for now. The tag is useful especially
for the projects that are adopted universally in production, which means
there are lots of people care about the stability and maintainability of
the projects. It's good for those projects to follow some policies to
achieve that.

However, Trove is no longer a project that was backed by Tesora, the
previous PTL came from Tesora left, all of the core reviewers left.
Until now, I've never heard there is company using Trove in production
except a private cloud in Samsung, maybe there are some others, but
seems they don't care about the open source community[2]. As mentioned
in my PTL candidacy, the highest priority for Trove is to give the
potential users confidence that the project is still actively
maintained, the team(well, mostly myself) is trying very hard to improve
DevStack and improve the way to build Trove guest image, in the near
future, I will solve the security issue as well, because those issues
were always asked when the developers or operators started the project
evaluation. With all that said, we need to decide what is going to be
backported by ourselves, sometimes even features or patches that don't
satisfy the stable branch policy. I don't see there are many advantages
to involve Stable Branch Maintenance team.

Hopefully, the project could get the tag back in the future.

[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-April/004991.html
[2] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-January/001934.html

Change-Id: I14e1377e87b3fa16c1414ae9a780144d48ca213e

As a LaTeX enthusiast (there are dozens of us) I definitely support doing this. But, I think you'll find it's a bit more difficult than simply calling 'build-sphinx -b latex'. In many cases the sphinx generated LaTeX is invalid or doesn't properly compile for many different reasons. 

For example, I spent some time a few years ago doing this in Nova: https://github.com/openstack/nova/commit/62575dd40e5b7698d9ba54641558246489f0614e

Which, besides that workaround script, resulted in a couple patches to sphinx to address some of the issues. That being said I expect the sphinx support has probably improved in the past 4 years, but I still expect there to be a lot of edge cases around this. Especially where we use more advanced features in sphinx. Have people tried to actually build PDFs on project documentation recently just to gauge how much work this actually is? Like I know for a fact that on both Nova and Tempest the output latex does not compile."}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2019-03-26 18:55:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 6547, 'date': '2019-03-26 19:01:13.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

That's a good idea. Is this something you can help me with? I need to fix up some of the wording for clarification in the mean time."}, {'account_id': 10607, 'date': '2019-03-27 13:38:47.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Brief conversation with Andreas and Doug.

We have two options for a POC:
1. To build 1 PDF out of doc/source for each repo and name it repo-$version.pdf so it's easy to have the theme add a link.  Done within the documentation job and not via tox.ini. This would mean we would only have to edit the conf.py files to add the latex output settings.
2. Add as a shell script to openstackdocstheme and call from tox.ini. It would first build a HTML page, and then checks for the main text components and tries to build a PDF. 

Does anyone have any particular thoughts or feelings on this? I am happy to champion this, but as far as technical implementation goes, I am going to need to work with a partner. Suggestion so far is Stephen Finucane as the docs PTL. But open to suggestion if anyone would like to help flesh this out a bit further."}, {'account_id': 15334, 'date': '2019-03-27 15:08:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-03-26 11:09:06.000000000', 'message': 'Add PDF doc generation for project docs goal for Train

This is designed to be a small, accessible goal for
the community. My understanding is that we no longer
require infra support to complete this goal, but I have

commit_message:
Add PDF doc generation for project docs goal for Train

This is designed to be a small, accessible goal for
the community. My understanding is that we no longer
require infra support to complete this goal, but I have
added Monty Taylor to the review just in case.

Change-Id: I1afda7ec016007de72fcbdb53aa9704fcba52f78

commit_message:
Fix some tempest values

changes the default admin_domain_scope to false as we do not provide
an admin scoped credentials in the default deployment

drops volume-feature-enabled -> api_v1/api_v3 as its deprecated and
instead use catalog_type to let tempest know which version to use

drop identiti-feautre-enabled -> api_v2 as its deprecated

Change-Id: I508b5d3e59b33e2c37155918ce99504e1b760210

We need to pass the config file to tempest cli so it can run from

As a side effect, we need to also pass the concurrency value to the cli
as it cannot infer it by itself

Change-Id: I897951cbbe39152767123387dff43109bef84cc6

commit_message:
Fix tempest test script

We need to pass the config file to tempest cli so it can run from
anywhere

As a side effect, we need to also pass the concurrency value to the cli
as it cannot infer it by itself

Change-Id: I897951cbbe39152767123387dff43109bef84cc6

[{'created': '2019-04-26 11:58:43.000000000', 'message': 'Run nova_cell_v2_discover_hosts.py on every deploy run

Change I1a159a7c2ac286373df2b7c566426b37b7734961 moved the dicovery
to run on a single compute host to not race on simultanious nova-manage
commands. This change make sure we run the discover on every deploy run
which is required for scaling up events.

Change-Id: Iba7a4aeeeeb94ffbbaf4bb757672091807301494
Related-bug: 1824445
'}]
commit_message:
Run nova_cell_v2_discover_hosts.py on every deploy run

Change I1a159a7c2ac286373df2b7c566426b37b7734961 moved the dicovery
to run on a single compute host to not race on simultanious nova-manage
commands. This change make sure we run the discover on every deploy run
which is required for scaling up events.

Change-Id: Iba7a4aeeeeb94ffbbaf4bb757672091807301494
Related-bug: 1824445

commit_message:
renderspec: convert to singlespec

We'd like to prefer / use the python3 version of renderspec
in openSUSE going forward.

Change-Id: I7df7915c6014c14280e148da82c384ef3601d51c

commit_message:
WIP: Use ksa adapter for cinder client

nova.volume.cinder.cinderclient now uses the common get_ksa_adapter
utility to create an Adapter from common keystoneauth1 configuration
options if the legacy [cinder] config options catalog_info and
endpoint_template are not specified.  In this code path, version
discovery is also performed via the Adapter.

As part of blueprint use-ksa-adapter-for-endpoints, which was mostly
completed in Queens except for this change, this provides a
consistent mechanism for endpoint communication from Nova.

Change-Id: If5b53fe1bf99d9983baddc0db266754e2e044519

[{'account_id': 25402, 'date': '2019-04-16 09:57:50.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 25402, 'date': '2019-04-17 08:33:21.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

We're waiting to have packages promoted from nautilus-testing to nautilus-release: this step is really important  because we need to make sure that all the osp components have the 14.x ceph packages, so this is a review to make us able to test scenario00{1,4} in the review https://review.openstack.org/#/c/651239"}, {'account_id': 13861, 'date': '2019-04-17 10:16:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1

What about take this patch and revert after we have promotion of openstack containers with nautilus ceph packages. Considering the fact: since ceph rpms are installed only in few container images, jobs time due to container updates should not be much.'}, {'account_id': 25402, 'date': '2019-04-17 11:34:06.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 25402, 'date': '2019-04-17 11:37:08.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3: Commit message was updated.'}, {'account_id': 25402, 'date': '2019-04-17 11:41:39.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

I agree with @yatin, let's keep this patch right now and we can revert it later (after promotion): this can allow us to move forward to get Nautilus here."}, {'account_id': 13861, 'date': '2019-04-17 12:16:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 10969, 'date': '2019-04-18 18:06:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 25402, 'date': '2019-04-23 11:04:37.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 6796, 'date': '2019-04-23 13:56:10.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: Code-Review+2

sorry guys, it's unclear to me which repos will containers prep step use without this change?"}, {'account_id': 25402, 'date': '2019-04-23 14:39:12.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 13861, 'date': '2019-04-24 07:41:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Code-Review+1

It can be reverted once openstack containers with ceph-nautilus packages are promoted to docker.io'}, {'account_id': 6796, 'date': '2019-04-24 12:22:54.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: Code-Review+2

> It can be reverted once openstack containers with ceph-nautilus
 > packages are promoted to docker.io

but this doesn't look like something we'll want to remove, that's why I was curious *what* was provisioning the luminous repos on the nodes before this change?"}, {'account_id': 13861, 'date': '2019-04-24 13:41:04.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

> > It can be reverted once openstack containers with ceph-nautilus
 > > packages are promoted to docker.io
 > 
 > but this doesn't look like something we'll want to remove, that's
 > why I was curious *what* was provisioning the luminous repos on the
 > nodes before this change?

@gfidente, so before this change, luminous packages are added in openstack-containers during the promotion phase[1]. periodic-tripleo-centos-7-master-containers-build-push[2] build all the containers, then these containers are tested with all other jobs in [1], once all jobs pass, build containers are pushed to docker.io and then those containers are used in CI jobs like in this patch.

So this change was required for nautilus transition, as the openstack containers have luminous packages and in CI to pass before promotion we need nautilus packages in containers, this patch will do that.
@gfindente sorry if i am not explaining clearly. If something else is missing let me know i can check.

[1] https://github.com/rdo-infra/review.rdoproject.org-config/blob/master/zuul.d/tripleo.yaml#L47-L110
[2] https://review.rdoproject.org/zuul/builds?job_name=periodic-tripleo-centos-7-master-containers-build-push"}, {'account_id': 16312, 'date': '2019-04-24 13:48:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 18002, 'date': '2019-04-24 14:23:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}, {'account_id': 18002, 'date': '2019-04-24 14:35:55.000000000', 'content': 'Removed Workflow+1 by John Fulton <fulton@redhat.com>
'}, {'account_id': 9592, 'date': '2019-04-26 12:16:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

check-rdo'}, {'account_id': 18002, 'date': '2019-04-26 14:54:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Workflow+1'}, {'account_id': 25402, 'date': '2019-04-26 19:47:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

recheck'}]

commit_message:
Added quickstart-centos-ceph-nautilus repo

Added this repo to make containers able to get the latest
nautilus packages and test scenario00{1,4} with these new
conditions; we can revert this commit when the packages
will become available.

Change-Id: I743a002e5d21a3a150727fda2117a04d4c389d38

commit_message:
Remove redis from controller element

Redis has been containerized in Pike already and having the package
in the overcloud-full image makes it problematic during upgrade/update.

This patch should be backported all the way down to Pike.

More info: https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1693625

Change-Id: I52fa31cb0556917b6a9d0cdd66085b7197db35ee
(cherry picked from commit 1ab58f20c91268ba60c16db4e6cd8b55335b2930)

commit_message:
fix storage.yaml to write environments/storage/nova-nfs.yaml

753a3504184d966c63121ca95bc0135afbc83a75 removed ceph entries
from sample-env-generator/storage.yaml which resulted in nova-nfs
and cinder-netapp-config to be in the same section. Therefore
environment_generator.py did not update the nova-nfs.yaml .

Also add quotes to the nfs version as they are required in
the resulting nova-nfs.yaml .

Closes-Bug: #1825374

Change-Id: I209480f209e3a8841362ea619b1c9b073c89f338
(cherry picked from commit 1c241362ff8df360a27b4fc06af0203d4e461c1f)

commit_message:
Place upper bound on python-dracclient version

The idrac hardware type requires python-dracclient versions greater than
or equal to 1.5.0 and less than 3.0.0.

This defines the upper bound to be less than 3.0.0 to make it easier to
backport to stable/stein. It was originally proposed against
stable/stein -- https://review.openstack.org/#/c/645956/ . Reviewers
asked that it be submitted against master first --
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/645956/1/driver-requirements.txt@12 --
and then backported to stable/stein.

The ironic master and stable/stein branches are compatible with
python-dracclient releases less than 3.0.0. Note that
python-dracclient's stable/stein branch was created off of tag 2.0.0.
The ironic stable/stein branch follows tag 12.1.0, which was created on
March 21. The python-dracclient tag 3.0.0 was created after that, on
April 4. The upper bound on master will be updated to less than 4.0.0 by
a follow-on change.

A related change has been proposed for stable/rocky --
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/651657/ . It will be backported to
stable/queens and prior after it merges.

Change-Id: I5f6d6be53aec9d72e8ba5cfa436f12e01966f871
(cherry picked from commit 708319742db6fc664559d5c23aa8ceeb0a7cdad6)

commit_message:
Allow NovaNfs parameters to be role specific

Currently, TripleO does not support to have an NFS backend as Nova Ephemeral storage on
selected roles. An admin should be allowed to create Compute role(s) for InstanceHA
having NFS shared storage used then by selected workloads while leaving the majority of
the workloads on standard compute nodes without InstanceHA and shared storage.

Closes-Bug: 1823712

Change-Id: I2702a022565a130ab339d165cb2252ad67d1162e
(cherry picked from commit 1295868ddd003cd93c8bc0b9fddac4eb710dc638)
(cherry picked from commit 0cd185954ce84fd603edecf55983ee7be4a1e0c7)
(cherry picked from commit 4d478753b7095c33932df92eb2fe54eab536b00b)

commit_message:
Allow NovaNfs parameters to be role specific

Currently, TripleO does not support to have an NFS backend as Nova Ephemeral storage on
selected roles. An admin should be allowed to create Compute role(s) for InstanceHA
having NFS shared storage used then by selected workloads while leaving the majority of
the workloads on standard compute nodes without InstanceHA and shared storage.

Closes-Bug: 1823712

Change-Id: I2702a022565a130ab339d165cb2252ad67d1162e
(cherry picked from commit 1295868ddd003cd93c8bc0b9fddac4eb710dc638)
(cherry picked from commit 0cd185954ce84fd603edecf55983ee7be4a1e0c7)

commit_message:
Skip boostrap-ansible on upgrades if already run

Skips bootstrap-ansible on a rerun if it has already run
previously.

Moves the working directory creation to it's own function
so that the lock directory is created earlier.

Change-Id: I156e0143991c79cc2f664a98b6cd22353c01b55d
(cherry picked from commit e4ae0931f19242f947e463b41132826f83c5c278)

commit_message:
Support endpoint updates in bootstrap

The current bootstrap command does not update the endpoints, but
does update many other settings.

It's very convenient to have a way to update endpoints from the
bootstrap command. One such use case is when bootstrap is run from
a configuration management tool such as ansible, and the endpoint
URLs need to be updated.

Change-Id: I2b1cb53701c3e5fb2d91c14d9c792beadd1dbbc2

commit_message:
Support redfish inside a fencing yaml file

Currently the only working and supported fencing devices are via IPMI
(and partially via xvm). With this change we add support for redfish
fencing devices. Note that the support is currently only when the
fencing parameters are defined by hand. More work will be needed to
support redfish inside the 'overcloud generate fencing' command.
The syntax used will look like the following:
parameter_defaults:
  EnableFencing: true
  FencingConfig:
    devices:
    - agent: fence_redfish
      host_mac: 52:54:00:b8:9a:90
      params:
        ipaddr: 172.16.0.1
        ipport: 8000
        login: admin
        passwd: password
        systems_uri: /redfish/v1/Systems/compute-0
        ssl_insecure: true
    - agent: fence_redfish
      host_mac: 52:54:00:d2:8e:30
      params:
        ipaddr: 172.16.0.1
        ipport: 8000
        systems_uri: /redfish/v1/Systems/compute-1
        ssl_insecure: true
        login: admin
        passwd: password
    - agent: fence_redfish
      host_mac: 52:54:00:8a:da:e4
      params:
        ipaddr: 172.16.0.1
        ipport: 8000
        login: admin
        passwd: password
        systems_uri: /redfish/v1/Systems/controller-0
        ssl_insecure: true
    - agent: fence_redfish
      host_mac: 52:54:00:69:82:4c
      params:
        ipaddr: 172.16.0.1
        ipport: 8000
        login: admin
        passwd: password
        systems_uri: /redfish/v1/Systems/controller-1
        ssl_insecure: true

Note that for this to work https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1677023
needs to be fixed first. Tested this with the fix for the above rhbz and
the depends-on and got correctly fencing devices configured:
 stonith-fence_redfish-52540069824c     (stonith:fence_redfish):        Started controller-1
 stonith-fence_redfish-5254008adae4     (stonith:fence_redfish):        Started controller-2
 stonith-fence_redfish-5254004c56a8     (stonith:fence_redfish):        Started controller-1

Depends-On: I96fa203c706858f13d5bd6732c31003ecb193b62

Change-Id: Ic85855b6789dbad918f709fdeeabc6934876ce72

commit_message:
Run nova-manage as root to prevent wrong nova-manage.log permissions

To verify if the default cell is created we run a nova-manage command.
Right now this is triggered as root and not as nova like the otheres.
In case it is the first time on the node it creates the nova-manage.log
with root user and follow up call as nova user will fail.

Related-bug: 1820590

Change-Id: I56a961615c0afa748a42c25d4614637275b7c33b

commit_message:
MetricsQdr: Build sslProfiles without internal TLS

sslProfiles submitted as a parameter are not created when internal_tls
is not true. This change adds the ability also create ad-hoc
sslProfiles when internal TLS is not used.

Change-Id: I07b79c398ea900f388e75d25eddd8853abb9e5fb

messages: [{'account_id': 14985, 'date': '2019-04-26 13:47:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Cherry Picked from branch master.'}, {'account_id': 3153, 'date': '2019-04-26 14:04:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-04-26 13:47:25.000000000', 'message': "tripleo-bootstrap: ensure network service is enabled & started

We are using 'network' service provided by 'network-scripts' which is
deprecated in RHEL8/CentOS8/Fedora28 but os-net-config doesn't support yet
NetworkManager. Until it happens, we need to ensure that network is started
at boot, as it'll take care of restarting the network interfaces managed by
OVS. Note that OVS unit service is already configure to start before
network.service.
See https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1701866 for context.

Change-Id: Ib2ca3830e3c3a79cdea93cdb8976757d0697811d
(cherry picked from commit 2d52d46702c7c1effe40bbdf03063673d9ef5488)
"}]
commit_message:
tripleo-bootstrap: ensure network service is enabled & started

We are using 'network' service provided by 'network-scripts' which is
deprecated in RHEL8/CentOS8/Fedora28 but os-net-config doesn't support yet
NetworkManager. Until it happens, we need to ensure that network is started
at boot, as it'll take care of restarting the network interfaces managed by
OVS. Note that OVS unit service is already configure to start before
network.service.
See https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1701866 for context.

Change-Id: Ib2ca3830e3c3a79cdea93cdb8976757d0697811d
(cherry picked from commit 2d52d46702c7c1effe40bbdf03063673d9ef5488)

messages: [{'account_id': 11491, 'date': '2019-01-28 15:15:03.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 17888, 'date': '2019-02-19 13:33:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 18575, 'date': '2019-03-19 13:57:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 14985, 'date': '2019-04-25 23:14:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}, {'account_id': 14985, 'date': '2019-04-26 13:51:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:\n\nrecheck'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-01-28 15:15:03.000000000', 'message': 'Retire the undercloud-selinux-mode validation

Since the containerized undercloud (Rocky Release and above), all the
validations are running from the 'mistral_executor' container. This container
doesn't have and cannot have its own separate SELinux Policies, SELinux will
always appear the be "disabled" in the container, though it is running on the
undercloud host.

This patch retires this validation.

Change-Id: I39cb5e0672c5080ff6d3365e0f56c3e27d19894f
Signed-off-by: Gael Chamoulaud <gchamoul@redhat.com>
'}]
commit_message:
Retire the undercloud-selinux-mode validation

Since the containerized undercloud (Rocky Release and above), all the
validations are running from the 'mistral_executor' container. This container
doesn't have and cannot have its own separate SELinux Policies, SELinux will
always appear the be "disabled" in the container, though it is running on the
undercloud host.

This patch retires this validation.

Change-Id: I39cb5e0672c5080ff6d3365e0f56c3e27d19894f
Signed-off-by: Gael Chamoulaud <gchamoul@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Allow NovaNfs parameters to be role specific

Currently, TripleO does not support to have an NFS backend as Nova Ephemeral storage on
selected roles. An admin should be allowed to create Compute role(s) for InstanceHA
having NFS shared storage used then by selected workloads while leaving the majority of
the workloads on standard compute nodes without InstanceHA and shared storage.

Closes-Bug: 1823712

Change-Id: I2702a022565a130ab339d165cb2252ad67d1162e
(cherry picked from commit 1295868ddd003cd93c8bc0b9fddac4eb710dc638)

commit_message:
Add role implication note to basic-default-roles

Expanding upon the Risk Mitigation section of the spec. Note that
role implications will be created admin->member->reader regardless of
whether or not a new role was created during bootstrap.

Change-Id: Ie5cfd122554ccb06be3a7b165209c6b9c3f453db

commit_message:
fix leaks VM when creating node failured

This patch update physical_id of node even in case recover node failured
if Vm is created.

Change-Id: I8a8bc60913f56173fb5d9425e86d96a0a0f8eb4b
Closes-Bug: #1820838

[{'created': '2019-04-24 11:14:07.000000000', 'message': 'Make the JSON RPC server work with both IPv4 and IPv6

Binding to 0.0.0.0 by default results in inability to work with IPv6,
which is a probable cause of Bifrost gate failures on some nodepool
providers. Using :: solves it.

Change-Id: Ic5c4c9b541c826ccf3025877f7c829fd34d0be6e
(cherry picked from commit 18fdc447efe525c8d4edf75a401fbf7580a352ff)

commit_message:
Make the JSON RPC server work with both IPv4 and IPv6

Binding to 0.0.0.0 by default results in inability to work with IPv6,
which is a probable cause of Bifrost gate failures on some nodepool
providers. Using :: solves it.

Change-Id: Ic5c4c9b541c826ccf3025877f7c829fd34d0be6e
(cherry picked from commit 18fdc447efe525c8d4edf75a401fbf7580a352ff)

commit_message:
[ironic] create pike-em tag against final releases

This is a procedural review to transition pike into extended maintenance by
creating the pike-em tag

It's possible that the release isn't needed (for example if there are no code
changes sine the previous release, sadly that's non-trivial to detect en masse.

If you are the PTL or release liaison for this team please +1 this review
if it is ready or -1 and take over the review to correct mistakes.

Change-Id: I065d261cc6f1294d7b344800d75d5aa718fefd02

commit_message:
[nova] create pike-em tag against final releases

This is a procedural review to transition pike into extended maintenance by
creating the pike-em tag on the nova deliverables.

The hash used for the pike-em tag should match the last release on the
stable/pike branch.

Change-Id: I261b7116750bb678c5cc129d3e3e080efec3998f

commit_message:
Correct signature on fake_get_availability_zones

This hardens tests by ensuring callers are using the
correct args (even though the fake method doesn't do
anything with them).

Change-Id: Ie5a95d6cce4cd914d5d7ca52b5524985e691a786

[{'created': '2019-04-26 18:59:57.000000000', 'message': "tooz: stop requiring enum34 on python3

When targetting python3 >= 3.6, enum34 is unnecesary as it is
a backport of enum from 3.4. We should only require it for python 2.x.
python < 3.5 isn't supported anymore anyway.

Change-Id: Ie446f3d8b51fe67a99914d54552f0e02aebaf75a
(cherry picked from commit 4c24f3410e442627cb6ad3ab8bdd79260f12d04c)
"}]
commit_message:
tooz: stop requiring enum34 on python3

When targetting python3 >= 3.6, enum34 is unnecesary as it is
a backport of enum from 3.4. We should only require it for python 2.x.
python < 3.5 isn't supported anymore anyway.

Change-Id: Ie446f3d8b51fe67a99914d54552f0e02aebaf75a
(cherry picked from commit 4c24f3410e442627cb6ad3ab8bdd79260f12d04c)

[{'account_id': 25877, 'date': '2019-04-24 14:29:16.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 3153, 'date': '2019-04-24 14:35:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

is this a backport? I would like to see the usage of git cherry-pick -x if yes.'}, {'account_id': 25877, 'date': '2019-04-24 14:42:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

This is a new patch and specific to Queens (and it still mirrors how it is handled in Rocky). I could not find any specific patch from Rocky that added these. In my test lab, I verified that this fixes the problems with some of the config-download backports mentioned in the BugZilla.'}, {'account_id': 7144, 'date': '2019-04-24 15:06:04.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

it looks like it's broken up across several patches:

Ied0f9422473bdf6d4fedd061c292725edd33feaa
Icfdd8cf29df6499ac3f1c834ade1368acc6a2947
Ic8863addb88ababfdc9504a141d420af6ce0a321

In the first patch, you would want just the changes that are made for setting the status in the config_download_deploy workflow.

The last 2 patches could probably be backported cleanly after that.

Or, we can go with a whole new patch as long as we make sure it mirrors the status setting behavior of those above patches."}, {'account_id': 25877, 'date': '2019-04-24 15:37:24.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2: Commit message was updated.'}, {'account_id': 25877, 'date': '2019-04-24 15:39:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

The commit message now reflects that this is a condensed version of those 3 patches and that it is specific to Queens (not a backport).'}, {'account_id': 7144, 'date': '2019-04-24 18:01:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 14985, 'date': '2019-04-26 15:49:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]

[{'created': '2019-04-24 14:29:16.000000000', 'message': "Set the deployment status on Mistral deployment tasks.

report updated and accurate information about the deployment.

Resolves: rhbz#1688461
Change-Id: Ie92d0e744c86c55c8ec2de18f47c3ce36f1c5a21
Signed-off-by: Luke Short <ekultails@gmail.com>
"}, {'created': '2019-04-24 15:37:24.000000000', 'message': "[Queens only] Set the deployment status on Mistral deployment tasks.

This allows 'openstack overcloud {status|failures}' to
report updated and accurate information about the deployment.

Partially implements from Rocky:
- Ied0f9422473bdf6d4fedd061c292725edd33feaa

commit_message:
[Queens only] Set the deployment status on Mistral deployment tasks.

This allows 'openstack overcloud {status|failures}' to
report updated and accurate information about the deployment.

Partially implements from Rocky:
- Ied0f9422473bdf6d4fedd061c292725edd33feaa
- Icfdd8cf29df6499ac3f1c834ade1368acc6a2947
- Ic8863addb88ababfdc9504a141d420af6ce0a321

Depends-On: Ib854689a3e606f18db7354427918fa8043ac28e0
Resolves: rhbz#1688461
Change-Id: Ie92d0e744c86c55c8ec2de18f47c3ce36f1c5a21
Signed-off-by: Luke Short <ekultails@gmail.com>

commit_message:
Avoid problematic recreation of virtualenv

Recreation of a virtualenv can cause errors like below when there are
leftover python processes running (can really happen).

IOError: [Errno 26] Text file busy

Also disables few annoying pip warnings.

Change-Id: I1c55e72acff024195f3ee6388dd2dfcbd1e5f466
Closes-Bug: #1826129
Related-Bug: #1792375

People seldom get their patch approved on the first try, so don't be

commit_message:
tooz: stop requiring enum34 on python3

When targetting python3 >= 3.6, enum34 is unnecesary as it is
a backport of enum from 3.4. We should only require it for python 2.x.
python < 3.5 isn't supported anymore anyway.

Change-Id: Ie446f3d8b51fe67a99914d54552f0e02aebaf75a

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-04-24 14:24:13.000000000', 'message': "Fix mock specs set to strings

The behavior of Mock(spec=foo) or Mock(spec_set=foo) when foo is not a
list is to interpret foo as a class or instance and derive the set of
attributes you're allowed to get (spec) and/or set (spec_set) based on
dir(foo) [1]. Thus if foo is a string, your mock will be set up to look
like a string (with attributes like index, find, startswith...).

So for example, if you see:

    Mock(spec='nova.objects.Instance')

...what was almost certainly intended was:

    Mock(spec=nova.objects.Instance)

This commit fixes all such cases in the nova codebase, making those
specs point to the actual classes as intended.

A subsequent commit will introduce a hacking rule to ensure this mistake
isn't repeated in the future.

[1] https://docs.python.org/3/library/unittest.mock.html#the-mock-class

Change-Id: I924edd474a798aa32bb8fb88ba6d84815a8bf93e
"}]
commit_message:
Fix mock specs set to strings

The behavior of Mock(spec=foo) or Mock(spec_set=foo) when foo is not a
list is to interpret foo as a class or instance and derive the set of
attributes you're allowed to get (spec) and/or set (spec_set) based on
dir(foo) [1]. Thus if foo is a string, your mock will be set up to look
like a string (with attributes like index, find, startswith...).

So for example, if you see:

    Mock(spec='nova.objects.Instance')

...what was almost certainly intended was:

    Mock(spec=nova.objects.Instance)

This commit fixes all such cases in the nova codebase, making those
specs point to the actual classes as intended.

A subsequent commit will introduce a hacking rule to ensure this mistake
isn't repeated in the future.

[1] https://docs.python.org/3/library/unittest.mock.html#the-mock-class

Change-Id: I924edd474a798aa32bb8fb88ba6d84815a8bf93e

commit_message:
Add support to set ovs_nb_connection

When using ovn provider unless set, it would try to
connect to 127.0.0.1.

Change-Id: If8eb685dd21791b65845afd44fb483592b8bcc0c
Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/653673

commit_message:
Add OS::TripleO::NeutronAZConfig

This service is mapped to OS::Heat::None by default, but when enabled,
it allows to configure defaut AZ for neutron, AZ for L3/DHCP agents and
AZ-aware network scheduling/routing. The zone name is the stack
name by default, but can be overridden with parameter values.

Change-Id: Ie5762c61cd615d7c115069381d6c43c468806e47
implements: blueprint split-controlplane-templates

Pyghmi was moved from openstack namespace to the x
namespace. As such the devstack plugin needs to match
up otherwise devstack fails in CI to clone as cloning

commit_message:
Fix pyghmi path

Pyghmi was moved from openstack namespace to the x
namespace. As such the devstack plugin needs to match
up otherwise devstack fails in CI to clone as cloning
is blocked if not in the projects list... Which it is,
as x/pyghmi.

Change-Id: I87bdf65dd2dac189642d0af6def2d0ed155f3c00
(cherry picked from commit bb8101ca950819a4d55af18d57b53c15ef51c836)

commit_message:
Update git.openstack.org to opendev.org

The project infrastructure is now hosted at opendev.org.

Kayobe projects have been moved from the openstack/ namespace to x/.

Change-Id: I16b523285eb34c1cd0eaf920aa4512d0ae1b4f05
(cherry picked from commit 5b9f85d715dd18b7a748bbee52980452a432a6d0)
